entries.title: BA to axe direct flights from London Heathrow to Beijing
entries.snippet: British Airways (BA) will eliminate its direct flights from London Heathrow to Beijing starting October 26, 2024. This decision comes after the resumption of the route in June 2023, following a three-year suspension due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. Although BA did not specify the reasons for the suspension, increasing costs and longer travel times due to the need to avoid Russian airspace amidst the Ukraine war have made Asia routes more challenging. BA will review the suspension periodically but does not plan to reinstate the service before November 2025. Passengers affected by the change will be offered rebooking options or full refunds. BA will continue flying daily to Shanghai and Hong Kong. The challenges of flying longer routes avoiding Russian airspace contrast with the competitive advantage Chinese airlines have by flying directly across Russia. Virgin Atlantic has also ceased its Shanghai flights, and tourism to China has not rebounded to pre-pandemic levels.

entries.title: Chinese airlines rush into Europe as western carriers retreat
entries.snippet: Chinese airlines are rapidly expanding their routes to Europe due to their ability to fly over Russian airspace, giving them a cost advantage over Western carriers who have to avoid Russia and thus face higher fuel costs. This advantage enables Chinese airlines to offer roughly 5% to 35% cheaper fares. Major European carriers like Scandinavian Airlines, Lufthansa, British Airways, and Virgin Atlantic have suspended some routes to China due to these increased costs. The capacity on China-Europe routes by Air China, China Eastern, and China Southern was 18% higher in October 2024 compared to the same month in 2019. Chinese airlines have also increased flights to the Middle East, significantly boosting connections to Saudi Arabia and the UAE. Despite these expansions, Chinese airlines continue to report financial losses due to China's slow economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic and competition from low-cost carriers. The economic slowdown is expected to continue hampering their profitability in 2025.

Chinese airlines protest US plan to ban their flights over Russian airspace
entries.snippet: China's largest state-owned airlines‚ÄîAir China, China Eastern, and China Southern‚Äîare protesting a U.S. proposal to ban them from flying over Russian airspace en route to or from the U.S. The U.S. Department of Transportation argues that Chinese carriers have an unfair cost advantage since American airlines cannot use Russian airspace due to a ban imposed by Moscow in 2022 in response to Western sanctions over the war in Ukraine. Chinese airlines claim the proposal would inconvenience passengers, raise operational costs, and increase ticket prices. China Eastern stated the ban would not serve public interest, while Air China estimated it would affect at least 4,400 passengers during peak travel seasons like Thanksgiving and Christmas. Aviation experts note that avoiding Russian airspace adds two to three hours to U.S.-China flights, impacting profitability for U.S. airlines. The Department of Transportation is currently taking public comments on the matter before finalizing the policy. Additionally, United Airlines has called for Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong‚Äôs flagship carrier, to be included in the proposed ban.

entries.title: China Airlines
Why British Airways bailed out of flying to Beijing
entries.snippet: British Airways (BA) has decided to scale back flights to Beijing due to economic considerations. Since Western sanctions following the Ukraine invasion in 2022 forced BA to avoid Russian airspace, flight durations between London and Beijing have increased from 10 to nearly 13 hours. This longer journey requires more fuel, leading to a 20 percent increase in fuel costs despite reduced air navigation expenses. Consequently, BA would need to raise average single economy fares by around ¬£85 to sustain profitability. Meanwhile, Chinese airlines benefit from shorter routes over Russian airspace, creating an economic imbalance. BA's decision aligns with its new codeshare arrangement with China Southern Airlines, allowing customers to book daily flights to Beijing through BA. Additionally, BA is reallocating resources to more profitable routes like transatlantic flights, as demand for China travel remains lower. BA's suspension of Beijing flights is temporary, planned from October to November 2025. BA executives are advocating for equalised airspace access to create fair competition.

entries.title: Air China passengers leaving London faced a 13-hour delay after engine trouble forced an unscheduled layover in Siberia
entries.snippet: Air China Flight 856, traveling from London Heathrow to Beijing, experienced a significant disruption after engine trouble forced an unscheduled landing in Nizhnevartovsk, western Siberia. The incident occurred five hours into the flight, prompting the pilots to declare a PAN-PAN urgency signal and divert the Boeing 777 aircraft. The flight had crossed into Russian airspace‚Äîstill accessible to Chinese carriers‚Äîbefore turning around. All 251 passengers and 15 crew members had to wait approximately 13 hours at the Siberian airport while a replacement aircraft was dispatched from Beijing. During the wait, Russia's aviation authority Rosaviatsiya provided folding beds, food, and beverages, especially for children and elderly passengers. The replacement plane arrived around 5 p.m. local time and departed four hours later, with the passengers finally reaching Beijing at 4:41 a.m. on Wednesday‚Äîover 13 hours later than the originally scheduled arrival. The faulty aircraft, identified as B-2033, remains grounded in Siberia.

entries.title: United Airlines Flight to China Forced to Turn Around After Pilot Realizes He's Forgotten His Passport: Reports
entries.snippet: A United Airlines flight from Los Angeles to Shanghai was forced to return to San Francisco after two hours of flight because the pilot realized he forgot his passport. The incident occurred on March 22, with flight UA 198 carrying 257 passengers and 13 crew members. Upon diversion, the airline arranged for a new crew to take the customers to their destination that evening, providing them with meal vouchers and compensation. The flight, initially set to land in Shanghai, was delayed by six hours, finally arriving at 12:48 a.m. on March 24. Passengers expressed frustration over the delay, some taking to social media to demand additional compensation. A United Airlines spokesperson apologized for the disruption.
